abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Polyploidy, or whole-genome duplication, is a common speciation mechanism in plants. An important barrier to polyploid establishment is a lack of compatible mates. Because self-compatibility alleviates this problem, it has long been hypothesized that there should be an association between polyploidy and self-compatibility (SC), but empirical support for this prediction is mixed. Here, we investigate whether the molecular makeup of the Brassicaceae self-incompatibility (SI) system, and specifically dominance relationships among <jats:italic>S-</jats:italic>haplotypes mediated by small RNAs, could facilitate loss of SI in allopolyploid crucifers. We focus on the allotetraploid species <jats:italic>Capsella bursa-pastoris</jats:italic>, which formed ~300 kya by hybridization and whole-genome duplication involving progenitors from the lineages of <jats:italic>Capsella orientalis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Capsella grandiflora</jats:italic>. We conduct targeted long-read sequencing to assemble and analyze eight full-length <jats:italic>S-</jats:italic>locus haplotypes, representing both homeologous subgenomes of <jats:italic>C. bursa-pastoris</jats:italic>. We further analyze small RNA (sRNA) sequencing data from flower buds to identify candidate dominance modifiers. We find that <jats:italic>C. orientalis</jats:italic>-derived <jats:italic>S-</jats:italic>haplotypes of <jats:italic>C. bursa-pastoris</jats:italic> harbor truncated versions of the male SI specificity gene <jats:italic>SCR</jats:italic> and express a conserved sRNA-based candidate dominance modifier with a target in the <jats:italic>C. grandiflora</jats:italic>-derived <jats:italic>S</jats:italic>-haplotype. These results suggest that pollen-level dominance may have facilitated loss of SI in <jats:italic>C. bursa-pastoris</jats:italic>. Finally, we demonstrate that spontaneous somatic tetraploidization after a wide cross between <jats:italic>C. orientalis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>C. grandiflora</jats:italic> can result in production of self-compatible tetraploid offspring. We discuss the implications of this finding on the mode of formation of this widespread weed.</jats:p>
